conclusion: To solve the problem, we need to determine the time during which there is an induced current in the frame as it moves through the magnetic field.
The key is to identify the intervals during which the frame is in the magnetic field.
The frame is a square with side length \( l \), and the width of the magnetic field is \( d \).
Since \( l < d \), the frame will be completely in the magnetic field for a certain period of time.
The frame enters the magnetic field when the left edge of the frame is at the boundary of the magnetic field.
The time taken for the left edge to reach the boundary is \( t_1 = \frac{l}{v} \).
The frame is in the magnetic field until the right edge of the frame is at the boundary of the magnetic field.
The time taken for the right edge to leave the magnetic field is \( t_2 = \frac{l}{v} \).
The total time during which the frame is in the magnetic field is \( t_{\text{in}} = t_2 - t_1 = \frac{l}{v} - \left( \frac{l}{v} - \frac{d}{v} \right) = \frac{d}{v} \).
The time during which there is an induced current in the frame is the time the frame is in the magnetic field, which is \( \frac{d}{v} \).
